title: Summary EDI study Behaviour 2023 Congress
text:
On this webpage, we will summarise all the current analyses, summaries of scripts and results used for the manuscript “Equity, diversity and inclusivity at the Behaviour 2023 Congress”.
The study consists of three main types of data: 1. Information on participants, collected during abstract submission and registration 2. Question asking behaviour during the congress 3. Post-congress survey
The manuscript will be structured differently, however the structure of this repository is based on the teams working on the different parts rather than the manuscript structure.

title: 5  Post Congress Survey
text:
6 Introduction
We circulated a survey after the end of the congress, addressed to all congress attendees as well as people who knew about the congress but did not end up registering. This post-congress survey consisted of a number of different partswhere some results are just presented in words, whereas others require modelling. Please navigate using the menu to jump to various sections of the analysis.
First, personal information on EDI metrics were collected, including gender, pronouns, career stage, nationality, affiliation, LGBTQIA+, age category and disability. Depending on the research question, each factor was used as a predictor and/or controlling variable.
This is what the distribution of answers for each metric looks like Figure 7.1. In addition to nationality and affiliation, we included a metric called “Expat status” which indicates whether a person’s country of affiliation is the same country as the country of their nationality.
All participants of the congress had to agree to the Code of Conduct. In the survey, we asked whether they read our inclusivity and accessibility page (this page included information about childcare, special needs, safe-space measures and the Code of Conduct, see the website) before making their decision to attend the Congress. The responses were as follows:
Yes, I read it: N = 168, % = 42.97
No: N = 100, % = 25.58
I saw it but did not read it : N = 118, % = 30.18
Out of those that read it, 43 people said that the inclusivity and accessibility page played a role in their decision to attend the congress (25.6%).
We decided to leave out this part as not all symposium conveners attended the congress, and multiple conveners could have filled out details on the same symposium.
A total of 5 people filled in the survey but did not attend the congress. 1 out of 5 submissions did not attend due to time restriction and 2 did not attend due to funding limitations. Other reasons were:
Participants were asked to answer on a scale of 1-7 how much they agree with the following three statements: 1) “I am an expert in my field”; 2) “I fully understand the work presented in the talks that I attended”; 3) “I fell comfortable speaking in English”. Below you can find the distribution of answers (Figure 11.1).
The congress experience questions can be divided into two sub-categories: a) questions about discrimination/harassment and reporting of this; b) sense of belonging.
In the post-congress survey, we asked three main questions with regards to question asking during the congress (and in general): 1) did you ask a question during the congress; 2) what are you main motivations to ask a question during this congress and in general and 3) what are you main hesitations to ask a question during this congress and in general. Question 2 and 3 are multiple-choice answers, where people can check if one or more motivators/hesitations are applicable to them.
We want to answer the question why women ask less questions than men do. To do so, we take a two-step approach: first we ask which motivations and hesitations are affected by gender, and second, we take those motivations and hesitations that are significantly affected by gender and ask if they are significantly associated with the probability for a person to ask a question.
Next, we aimed to answer which social identities evaluate EDI issues at STEM differently. More specifically, we asked survey participants three questions that were answered on a 7-point Likert scale (1 = strongly disagree to 7 = strongly agree):
Similar to the analysis of congress experience, we first modeled each of the six variables (nationality, gender, English level comfort, career stage, LGBTQI+, expat status and affiliation) in separate models as a single fixed effect, for each of the three questions (3x6 = 18 models). In this case, we do not model age nor career stage as these are correlated to career stage, and career stage (and therefore experience measured in years and number of positions) is more relevant to this particular question. In addition to including LGBTQI+ and gender in the model, we also compared a model that included the interaction between LGBTQI+ and gender in another model and compared this to those that did not include the interaction in an LRT.
The final model then only concluded the variables that explain a significant amount of variation (i.e. the LRT between the null and alternative model had a p-value < 0.05) in the three responses. We used the MASS::polr function again to fit the ordinal response variable (Likert scale data).
A total of 11 people used the free childcare service offered, of which 7 researchers would not have been able to attend the congress without. A total of 7 indicated that they would be able to attend more conferences if (free) childcare was available as a standard.
A total of 18 people indicated that they have some form of a disability, but 11 researchers did not inform us about this disability. Out of those that did, 0 indicated we were able to accommodate to their disability but it could have been better. The qualitative feedback includes some good examples, suggestions and tips for event organizers to make scientific conferences more accessible and inclusive for disabled researchers.

title: 3  Abstract submission, registration and awards
text:
3.1 Abstract submission
There were a total of 729 abstract submissions, of which the majority were submitted by women (456 / 729). 10 identified as gender queer and 14 preferred not to disclose their gender identity. A total of 59 nationalities were represented among those who submitted an abstract. The majority of the abstract submitters originated from Europe (504/729), followed by Asia (101/729), North America (64/729), South America (21/729), Oceania (20/729) and lastly Africa (8/729). Out of all who submitted an abstract, 336 were affiliated with another nation than their nationality (Expat status).
The majority of the submissions were aimed at a symposium (419). 392 were for or accepting of a poster spot, and 593 were aimed at a talk. 59 were invited speakers.

title: 3  Abstract submission, registration and awards
text:
3.2 Registration
There were a total of 727 registrations, the majority of which were submitted by women (451 / 727). 15 registrants identified as gender queer and 28 preferred not to disclose their gender identity. A total of 59 nationalities were represented among those who registered. The majority of registrations originated from Europe (481/727), followed by Asia (85/727), North America (48/727), Oceania (20/727), South America (18/727), and Africa (5/727). Almost half of registrants were early career researchers (360/727), followed by mid (274/727) and late (93/727) career researchers.

title: 3  Abstract submission, registration and awards
text:
3.3 Awards
A total of 14 awards were given at the congress. One Alcock award, 10 ‘best student talk’ awards and three poster awards. The winners were all affiliated with European (including UK) institutions, representing 7 nations. Most winners were associated with German institutions (7/13). The awards were given to 5 women and 3 men, however 6 did not wish to disclose their gender identity (See Figure 3.4).

title: 5  Post Congress Survey
text:
12.1 Discrimination and harassment
Participants were asked if they themselves experience discrimination and/or harassment (of any sort) at the congress and whether they reported it to the Awareness team, or if they witnessed someone else experiencing this.
A total of 11 people witnessed some form of discrimination or harassment, of which 2 cases were reported to the Awareness team
A total of 3 people witnessed somebody else receiving some form of discrimination or harassment, of which 1 case was reported to the Awareness team.
Reasons of not reporting the cases to the Awareness team included:

“The harassment was a case of someone pushing their own convictions unto others instead of being constructive, and was unrelated to gender/diversity issues.”

title: 5  Post Congress Survey
text:
12.2 Sense of belonging
Participants were asked to answer how much they agree with the following three statements: 1) “I felt heard during the conversations I had, both during Q&A sessions and social activities”; 2) “I felt comfortable being myself”; 3) “Attending the Behaviour 2023 congress helped me feel like I belong in my research field”.
The distribution of answers looks as follows (?fig-belong):
 Next, we can use generalized linear modelling to understand what EDI metrics might be associated with a lower sense of belonging, using the three questions described above as three separate response variables.
The approach I have taken so far is including each of the variables of interest as a single fixed effect in univariate models, and only the significant (p < 0.05) values were included in the final model. Here, I only present the final model for each of the three response variables. The variables of interest are: age, nationality, gender, english level comfort, career stage (to compare with age), expertise level, expat status and affiliation.
The models I used for these Likert scale responses are implemented using the polr function within the MASS package. I could not think of random effects t include in the model. The significance of a variable was assessed with a likelihood ratio test comparing the null model (only the intercept) with the alternative model.

12.2.1 Feeling heard
The variables that were not significantly associated with feeling heard were: nationality (sub-continent), affiliation (sub-continent), expat status and gender. The variables age, career stage and expertise rating were all significantly associated with sense of belonging, however they are all highly correlated with each other. We used AIC to determine which of the three models was the best one, and the model with the lowest AIC was the one that included expertise rating. Therefore, the final model included expertise rating and English comfort rating as predictors.

m_heard_null <- MASS::polr(as.factor(feeling_heard_rating) ~ 1, data = survey)
m_heard <- MASS::polr(as.factor(feeling_heard_rating) ~ 
                      expertise_rating + english_comfort_rating, data = survey)

title: 5  Post Congress Survey
text:
14.1 Workshops
A total of 21 people attended one of the EDI workshops. Reasons for attending the workshop were:

To improve the way I do research (N = 14)
To talk about my own EDI issues (N = 5)

title: 5  Post Congress Survey
text:
14.2 Symposium
A total of 66 respondents attended the EDI symposium. Reasons for attending the symposium were:

To improve the way I do research (N = 40)
To talk about my own EDI issues (N = 7)
To talk about others’ EDI issues (N = 12)
To learn about EDI issues (N = 40)

Other reasons to attend were: Knew one of the speakers, availability of time, to support the initiative, to see who else is engaging with EDI issues on a visible basis (e.g., the speaker), and to signal support for EDI,to hear how it is discussed at this conference; and to show support by attending
Out of the reported attendees, a total of 27 people report that the symposium will change the way they do research,and a total of 13 people report that this will maybe happen.

section: 13.1 Which motivations/hesitations are affected by gender?
text:
13.1 Which motivations/hesitations are affected by gender?
There are a total of 6 motivations + open answer and a total of 13 hesitations + open answer included in the survey (hereafter collectively referred to as ‘reasons’) + 6 Likert-scale data on what makes people more comfortable to ask a question:
Motivations and the percentage of total survey participants who ticked this motivation are:

Interest in the topic 87.6%
Making my voice heard 6%
Appraising the speaker’s work 21.5%
Deeper understanding 72.5%
Showing the audience and speaker my understanding of the topic 3.6%
Relevance for my own research 50%
Other 4.4%

Hesitations and the percentage of total survey participants who ticked this hesitation are:

Not feeling clever enough 31.3%
Afraid I misunderstood the content of the presentation 40.4%
I felt intimidated by the speaker 3.1%
I felt intimidated by the audience 19.2%
I felt intimidated by the setting (eg. size of the room) 9.1%
I felt intimidated by the session chair 0.5%
I did not think my question was relevant/important 39.6%
Afraid I would not not be able to phrase/articulate my question well 29%
I did raise my hand but was not chosen to ask a question 15.3%
There was no time left to ask my question 28.2%
I am too much of a introvert 23.3%
I would rather ask my question after the session, 1-1 with the speaker 45.3%
I did not have the confidence 22%
Other 4.7%

Conditions: * “I feel comfortable asking questions during Q&A sessions” * “I feel more comfortable asking questions to a speaker who is of my own gender” * “I feel more comfortable asking question when my own gender is represented in the audience” * “I feel more comfortable asking questions when the audience is smaller” * “I feel more comfortable asking questions when the session host of my own gender *”I feel more comfortable asking questions when I know the speaker”
We modeled each of the 25 reasons as follows: glm(reason ~ gender + career_stage, family = "binomial") where career_stage is one of 4 categories: early, mid, late or other. We included career stage to control for the variation this variable explains in the reason of asking or not asking a question. For the conditions that were answered on a Likert-scale, we modelled it as follows: MASS::polr(condition ~ gender + career_stage)
Significance of gender on the reason was concluded through a likelihood ratio test. The results of the model are summarized as follows:

There are additional columns in this summary that indicate if the reason was significantly affected by gender, and what the distribution of answers per gender category was like.
There are 11 reasons that significantly explain variation in question-asking probability:

2 motivators: being interested in the topic and making your voice heard
7 hesitations: not feeling clever enough, audience intimidation, not being chosen, no time, being too introverted, rather asking the question in private, and lack of confidence
2 conditions: if the speaker is of ones own gender and if they know the speaker

Only three of the hesitations are significantly affected by gender (see above). There is a counter-intuitive result for ‘not being chosen’ and ‘no time’, where ticking one of these options is associated with a higher likelihood of asking a question, and this is because we did not make a distinction between intended question asking (i.e. raising your hand) versus realized question asking (you were chosen to ask a question). The only condition that is affected by gender and explains variation in question asking probability is the gender of the speaker.
From these results we conclude that women are less likely to ask a question because they do not feel clever enough, they are intimidated by the audience, and/or due to a lack of confidence. Although women are more hesitant to ask their question because they are scared to formulate/articulate their question, this does not appear to explain the difference in men and women in actual asking of questions. Moreover, women feel more comfortable asking questions when the speaker is of their own gender.

15.2 EDI issues
The final model to assess how people perceived EDI issues in our field was more difficult to construct because there were a number of significant variables: the interaction between gender and LGBTQI+, nationality, affiliation, and expat status. title: 4  Question asking
text:
5 Introduction
At the congress, we collected data on question asking behaviour during Q&A sessions. Although ideally we would have assessed bias in question asking behaviour across multiple social identities, due to logistic and practical reasons, we focus on gender only, as this is the most conspicuous identity that can be observed in a real-life setting. We randomly sampled X% of all sessions at the congress, and ensured that at least 30% of the sessions were sampled by multiple observers so we could test for inter-observer reliability.
A total of 25 observers collected data on question-asking behaviour across the five days of talks. Talks were given in lecture halls of three different sizes: small (< X people), medium (X people) and large (X people). Because it is difficult to observe all people in large lecture rooms, these sessions were always sampled by two observers, and a double-sampled session would therefore mean the session was observed by four people. Each day was divided into two time sessions: the morning and the afternoon, each split in two by a coffee break. In general, any type of uncertainty in the data was noted down by the observers and accounted for during the analysis.
Observers were seated in the back corner of the lecture hall to get a better overview of the audience and to remain subtle when counting people. There are a few different meta-data variables that were used for the analysis: session ID, day number (1-5), lecture hall (1-9), symposium vs. general session, Different types of data were collected at different levels: session information, talk information, and question information.
Moreover, to ensure our study has practical implications, we wanted to investigate if the behaviour of the session host can help overcome gender-equality barriers. Previous studies have found that men are more likely to ask questions at scientific events (Hinsley et al., 2017), which is the consequence of a combination of many complex factors. These factors include both inherent differences between genders as well as the differences in research landscapes that people face. Scientific contribution such as question-asking is a product of scientific reputation, social reputation, discrimination and stereotyping, self-promotion and the positive feedback within this framework (Hinsley et al., 2017). If women are more encouraged to ask a question when a woman asks the first question, session hosts could play a role in battling inequality during scientific participation.
Therefore, for a subset of sessions (around 30%), we manipulated the session host behaviour. More specifically, we instructed session hosts to either give the first question after a talk to a woman or to a man. We semi-randomly assigned session hosts to either an unmanipulated or manipulated session. If the session host was part of the Organization Committee, they were automatically assigned to a manipulated session. Session hosts of unmanipulated sessions were unaware of our study and were not contacted prior or after the congress about the study. The session hosts of manipulated sessions were asked by email, 2 weeks prior to the congress, if they wanted to participate in our study, without mentioning the exact goal or what the task included. If the session host agreed (X/X cases), they were given instructions specific to their session. For each talk within their session, they were instructed to give the first question after a talk to a woman (condition ) or to a man (condition 2). The two conditions were randomly assigned across manipulated sessions while ensuring an equal ratio of conditions. ** note to self: left it here **
In the Methods section of the manuscript, we outline a few details: manual corrections and curation fo the data, how we combined data from multiple observers, if inferred gender matches with ones preferred pronouns, and if inferred age matches with one’s self-reported age.
We will explain the exact methods and results for each research question in detail below. However, here we will describe the general model set-up that we use to make it easier to follow later on. For most questions, the null hypothesis is that there is no gender-bias in question asking, meaning that the number of questions asked by women is proportional to the number of women in the audience. This means that if 70% of the audience is female, 70% of the questions should be asked by women if there were no gender bias. To formulate this into a statistical model, we used binomial mixed effect models that look as follows:
glmer(gender_questioner ~ 1 + (session_id/talk_id), family = "binomial", offset=boot::logit(audience_women_prop))
Where gender_questioner is a binary variable indicating whether a woman (1) asked a question or a man (0). The random effect structure accounts for the independence between talks of the same session. The offset argument is used to correct for the gender proportion in the audience, which was calculated based on the number of men in the audience and total audience size. If the intercept in the model is positive, this means that women are more likely to ask a question than men do when taking into account the audience gender proportion.
For all models, we exclude any questions that were asked by the host, were a follow-up (by the same person without another person asking a question in between), or when the question asker did not raise their hand. As a supplementary analysis, we repeated every model excluding data that any level of uncertainty, to ensure this uncertainty did not bias our results. Unless specified otherwise, we only look at the sessions that were untreated (i.e. session host was not contacted or instructed about anything).
-Jonas-
First, we want to answer whether in general, women ask less questions than men do at the congress.

title: 4  Question asking
text:
6.1 Session information
A session was hosted by 1-3 session hosts and contained up to 7 15-minute talk slots, or alternatively the symposia could include 30 minute-talk slots for invited speakers. For each session host, the gender (female, male, other), career stage and age class (< 35 years, 35-50, > 50 years) was noted down. Where possible, we gap-filled and corrected these data post-hoc based on publicly available information on the hosts and the registration survey. If the hosts swapped roles during the session, this was noted down.

title: 4  Question asking
text:
6.2 Talk information
At the start of each talk, the total audience size was counted, as well as the total number of men in the audience. Because more women than men attended the congress, we counted men only to speed up the counting process The session hosts, speaker, observers and technical assistants were excluded from these counts. Similar to above, for each speaker, the gender (female, male, other), career stage and age class (< 35 years, 35-50, > 50 years). In addition, the duration of the Q&A was noted down and whether the speaker talked for longer than their allocated time slot.

title: 4  Question asking
text:
6.3 Question information
For each question after each talk, we noted down the number of hands that were raised in total and by men only. Because this was more difficult to see in large rooms, two observers were always present in the large rooms where one counted the total number of hands raised and the other the number men who raised their hands only. For each person asking a question, the following were noted: the gender of the person asking the question, age class of the questioner, if there are words of positive appraisal given to the speaker, the type of question. Notes were taken if one of the following situations occurred: a person asked a question without raising their hand (jumper), the session host asked the question, the presenter chose who asked the question instead of the session host, an observer asked a question, a person asks multiple questions in one go, a person asks multiple questions in one Q&A but not consecutively,

title: 4  Question asking
text:
6.4 Inferring gender
The primary way of inferring a person’s gender for all of the purposes described above is by the pronouns printed on their nametag, which attendees can opt for during congress registration. If the nametag cannot be observed due to distance, we confirmed their pronouns after the congress where possible, if we knew their name and they had consented to print their pronouns on their name tags during congress registration. If the name tag does not contain the pronoun or this cannot be observed, we infered gender from appearance* (e.g. hair length, clothing, voice pitch, body size, name if stated when asking the question).

title: 4  Question asking
text:
6.5 Inferring career stage and age
The primary way of inferring a person’s career stage is through their title and/or academic position, which was occasionally mentioned at the start or end of a talk, or when a person introduces themselves. If this was not mentioned, we gap-filled these details after the congress based on publicly available data.
Age was divided into three categories: under 35, between 35-50, and above 50 years old. Age was inferred from a person’s appearance (facial features, hair colour, voice, clothing). We instructed observers to be careful to bias their age estimation by a person’s career stage, as these are not always directly linked to each other.
